title: 114_hr2013
content: The "Fitness Integrated Into Teaching Kids Act" or the "FIT Kids Act" amends the Carol M. White Physical Education Program to award grants for physical education programs for kindergarten through 12th-grade students. The FIT Kids Act allocates funds for grants to local educational agencies, community-based organizations, and states for physical education programs. 25% of funds exceeding $75,000,000 are reserved for state grants. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to local educational agencies and community-based organizations for physical education programs for K-12 students, including equipment, staff training, fitness education, motor skills instruction, and cognitive development. The Secretary awards grants for physical education programs focusing on cognitive concepts, social skills, nutrition, and teacher professional development. Extracurricular activities like team sports are not part of the assisted curriculum. Local agencies must submit applications for grants. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for initiating, expanding, or improving physical education programs to meet State standards. It includes provisions for private school and home-schooled students to participate in funded activities. Additionally, it mandates an annual report to demonstrate progress towards meeting State standards in order to continue receiving funding. The curr_chunk outlines the guidelines for using grant funds for physical education programs, including limits on administrative expenses and the federal share of program costs. It also emphasizes equitable distribution of grants among urban and rural areas and requires a report to Congress on program success in improving physical fitness. The curr_chunk recommends appropriate measures for the improvement of programs assisted under this section, focusing on physical fitness. "SEC. 5505. GRANTS TO STATES for improving programs focusing on physical fitness." The Secretary is authorized to award grants to States for comprehensive programs addressing physical activity, education, fitness, and nutrition based on research and needs analysis. States must submit applications detailing needs and improvement plans. The Secretary awards grants to States for comprehensive programs focusing on physical activity, education, fitness, and nutrition. States must submit applications outlining needs and improvement plans, including developing measurement systems, ensuring data quality, coordinating activities with other programs, and assisting local educational agencies. The State receiving a grant must reserve up to 5% for program administration, technical assistance, teacher development, and improving the State's implementation. The State should align activities with other funding sources, solicit and approve subgrant applications, consider analysis results for subgrant distribution, and address diverse geographic needs. The State receiving a grant must reserve up to 5% for program administration, technical assistance, teacher development, and improving the State's implementation. The State should establish a physical education requirement, develop a measurement system, and provide annual progress reports to local educational agencies. The State receiving a grant must establish a State reporting and information system to collect data for educational agencies. This data will be used to award subgrants, identify school and student needs, provide professional development for physical education and health teachers, and monitor subgrant activities. The State reporting system collects data on physical fitness, education, student health, and nutrition at the local educational agency level, including time spent on physical education, curriculum adherence, teacher certification, and number of schools. The State reporting system collects data on physical fitness, education, student health, and nutrition at the local educational agency level, including the number of schools with a school health council, square footage used for physical education, and data collection procedures for uniform statistics. The State collects data annually for planning and improvement of activities under this section. Subgrants are awarded based on need and enable local applicants to implement comprehensive programs promoting physical activity. The State awards subgrants based on need to promote physical activity, fitness, and nutrition. Priority is given to schools with high poverty levels. Applicants must submit an application to receive a subgrant. The subgrant recipients must implement programs promoting physical activity, fitness, and nutrition based on identified needs. They must use scientifically valid research for selected interventions and report data to the State educational agency. Access expansion policies should be established. The State must establish policies to expand access to quality physical activity opportunities, including school wellness policies. They should also consider the unique needs of students with disabilities and English learners. Each State receiving a grant must submit an annual report on the use of funds. The funds allocated for physical education activities must supplement, not replace, any existing Federal, State, or local funds.
